p: Thunderstorms occurring during the pollen season have been shown to induce severe asthma attacks in pollinosis patients [ 18, 19]. The thunderstorm-related epidemics are limited to late spring and summer when there are high levels of pollen grains in the atmosphere. The main hypotheses for thunderstorm-related asthma claim that thunderstorms can concentrate pollen grains at ground level which rupture due to osmotic shock and release allergenic particles of respirable size into the atmosphere [ 19].
